hints.content:
Let's interpret the frequency table.

Distance | Number of Kangaroos
- | - 
$8\dfrac12\text{ m}$| ${\mid}{\mid}{\mid}{\mid} = 4$ kangaroos
$10\dfrac12\text{ m}$ | $\mid\mid = 2$ kangaroos
$11\text{ m}$ | $\bcancel{\mid\mid\mid\mid}\mid = 6$ kangaroos
$12\text{ m}$| $\mid\mid\mid=3$ kangaroos
Each tick mark on the number line represents an interval of ${\dfrac{1}{2}\text { m}}$.

There were $4$ kangaroos that jumped a distance of $\blueD{8\dfrac12\text { m}}$.  

So, we place $4$ dots over $\blueD{8\dfrac12}$ on the number line.   

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled distance (meters) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, and 13. An unlabeled tick mark appears in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 4 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 8 and 9. !

hints.content: Now, let's graph the other measurements on the frequency table.

The correctly graphed measurements are:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled distance (meters) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, and 13. An unlabeled tick mark appears in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 4 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 8 and 9, 2 dots above the unlabeled tick mark between 10 and 11, 6 dots above 11, and 3 dots above 12. !

question.content:
A group of kangaroo friends had a jumping contest and measured their longest jumps to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{2} \text{ m}$. 

Distance | Number of Kangaroos
- | - 
$8\dfrac12\text{ m}$| ${\mid}{\mid}{\mid}{\mid}$
$10\dfrac12\text{ m}$ | $\mid\mid$
$11\text{ m}$ | $\bcancel{\mid\mid\mid\mid}\mid$
$12\text{ m}$| $\mid\mid\mid$

**Graph the measurements from the frequency table on the following line plot.**   
*Click above the line plot to make dots for each of the measurements.*

[[☃ plotter 1]]
